L1_summary_of_paper: This empirical study investigates how firms in business groups in emerging economies acquire R&D capabilities through multiplex intragroup network ties. The authors propose a contingency model explaining how three types of ties—buyer-supplier, equity, and director ties—individually and in combination affect R&D capability acquisition, and how these effects are moderated by network density. The theoretical framing integrates the resource-based view and social network theory, emphasizing tie content and structural context. Buyer-supplier ties are argued to provide specific technological knowledge; director ties provide generic knowledge and strategic information; equity ties supply financial capital. Hypotheses predict that buyer-supplier centrality will positively relate to R&D capability, that director and equity centrality will each strengthen this effect, and that high centrality in all three ties will yield the largest gains. Director network density is expected to strengthen the buyer-supplier effect, whereas equity network density is expected to weaken it. The study uses data on 188 listed affiliates in 123 Taiwanese business groups from 1981–1998, measuring R&D capability via stochastic frontier estimation. Results from GLS random-effects models support most hypotheses. The paper contributes by highlighting multiplexity and structural contingency in network-based capability acquisition and by introducing stochastic frontier estimation to capability measurement.
A1_citation: Mahmood, I. P., Zhu, H., & Zajac, E. J. (2011). Where can capabilities come from? Network ties and capability acquisition in business groups. Strategic Management Journal, 32(8), 820–848.
C3_metric_detail: Acknowledges emerging economy context with weaker institutions and underdeveloped markets, implying uncertainty for R&D activities.
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Uses archival data with clear operationalization; possible unobserved heterogeneity and endogeneity of network positions not fully addressed.
G1_construct_mapping_note: R&D capability aligns with capability efficiency constructs in RBV; network centrality aligns with embeddedness measures in network theory.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: Multiplex network ties have heterogeneous effects on capability acquisition depending on tie content.
Complementary resources across tie types enhance R&D capability.
Network structural context conditions the value of specific ties.
NA_reason_if_any: Empirical quantitative study, not theory-only or review.
I1_mechanism_statements: Buyer-supplier ties provide specific technological knowledge that enhances a firm's R&D capability.
Director ties provide generic knowledge and strategic information that complement technological knowledge from buyer-supplier ties.
Equity ties provide financial capital facilitating the exploitation of technological knowledge from buyer-supplier ties.
Dense director networks increase trust and information richness, amplifying the effect of buyer-supplier ties.
Dense equity networks increase competition for financial resources, reducing the marginal benefit of buyer-supplier ties.

I2_mediation_moderation_details.role_in_link: Reinforces buyer-supplier centrality's effect on R&D capability
Reinforces buyer-supplier centrality's effect on R&D capability
Positive moderator of buyer-supplier ties' impact on R&D capability
Negative moderator of buyer-supplier ties' impact on R&D capability

J1_main_findings_summary: Buyer-supplier centrality positively relates to R&D capability.
Director centrality strengthens the positive effect of buyer-supplier centrality.
Equity centrality strengthens the positive effect of buyer-supplier centrality.
High centrality in all three ties yields the greatest R&D capability gains.
Director network density amplifies the buyer-supplier effect.
Equity network density diminishes the buyer-supplier effect.
K1_contribution_summary: This paper shows that capability acquisition in business groups depends on both the type and structure of network ties, highlighting multiplexity and structural contingency. It extends RBV by identifying external, network-based sources of capabilities, and introduces stochastic frontier estimation to capability measurement in strategic management.
